snippet: The Labor Department reported a gain of 142,000 jobs in September, and the August figure was revised downward, though unemployment remained at 5.1 percent.
abstract: Analysts say jobs report, which shows flat unemployment rate, contraction in labor force and stagnant wages, will likely halt any plans to raise interest rates by Federal Reserve; note hardest hit are employees in low-skill jobs and point to continued global economic hardship as key to lagging US employment growth.

byline.contributor: Peter Baker contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The Labor Department reported a gain of 142,000 jobs in September, and the August figure was revised downward, though unemployment remained at 5.1 percent.

headline.main: Grim Jobs Report Is Likely to Delay a Move by the Fed on Rates
headline.print_headline: Grim Jobs Report Is Likely to Delay a Move by the Fed on Rates
